story:
My name is Emma Stewart. I'm twenty two years old and grew up in Brisbane, Australia. I come from a hard working, middle class family and have one older sister. I have recently completed studies in massage therapy and have embarked on running my own business. Prior to massage therapy, I have been in the Disability Sector as a Support Worker and a Case Worker. I currently run Fitness Days for People with a Disability. ‘Fit4You Brisbane’ was the first project run in June this year, where circuit training, ball games, Thai chi & wheelchair rugby were enjoyed by all.
I've been playing sport all my life. I first officiated basketball at the age of eleven. In 2011, at the age of twenty I was recruited by the Head Official of Wheelchair Rugby, Terry Vineyard to come and trial officiating Wheelchair Rugby. I fell in love with the sport and have since been committed to the game, the progression and development of the Sport and first and foremost the players. Over the last three years I have been officiating local, State, National Comps, as well as an International Test last year; Australia VS Japan.

I have been selected as a candidate for my International Accreditation; this is a rare and excellent opportunity for my development and progression as an official. I will be representing Australia as an Official Wheelchair Rugby Referee for the IWRF Asia-Oceania Championships held in Pretoria, South Africa this November.

I currently referee in the National Wheelchair Rugby League and the Queensland Wheelchair Rugby League. In addition to refereeing Wheelchair Rugby at local, state & National level, I also Referee and play Basketball at club and state level.

A quick history of my development as a Referee in Wheelchair Rugby:
- Started Local Comp in April 2011
- National League May 2011 – C Badge
- National League July 2012 – B Badge· 
- Nominated to Grade as an International Referee - April 2013
- Travelled and officiated the Australian Paralympic Team on Camps - 2013

I am to complete my A Badge, which is an internal Grading System of Australia in October at the last Australian Paralympic Team Camp prior to the Asia-Oceania Pacific Games, where I will grade for my International Badge.

By going to the Asia-Oceania Pacific Games, it not only assist in my development, but enable me to pass on my experience to others in local and national competitions and to furthermore be more accredited to bring Wheelchair Rugby to North QLD.
I look forward to being one of the youngest in the World to get this accreditation in the sport Wheelchair Rugby and to continue to contribute to the community of disabilities through my passion of fitness and sport.



I'm looking to raise about 2,500 dollars to get my International Badge this November. Below is a summary of my financial needs in order to do so:
- Flights $2,000
- Insurance $200
- Certification Fee $100
- Uniform $200

Anything you can contribute will mean the world to me!

I understand that not everyone will be able to help with a donation, but I want you to know that I sincerely appreciate you taking the time of your busy schedule to read my story and I ask that you share this link with your friends, family, acquaintances, co-workers, and anyone else who think may wish to assist in me achieving my goal and dedication to the community of disabilities.

story:
This campaign have been re-posted and now active in HERE  http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/prisecu-personal-gps-tracker--2

GetIT Marketing is a IT company involve in research and development. We have dedicated team and in business for 2 years. We are proud to present our latest development private security device, PriSecu. We are committed to make the delivery even if we don't meet the necessary funding target. Introductory price for PriSecu has been set for $109 will be sold through www.prisecu.com.




When it comes to your loved ones, you cannot compromise with their security. They are most valuable to your life, and protecting them is your responsibility. Unfortunately, hectic work schedule makes it impossible for you to keep a constant eye on your beloved ones. No wonder, you will be worried for them and it also doesn’t make any sense to control their freedom. That’s why we present to you “PriSecu” – a next-generation, cutting-edge Private Security Device that provides reliable information about your loved ones, washing away all your worries. At the same time, it will also intimate you immediately whenever a person is in danger, met with an emergency health issue, or goes beyond the preset radius area.


PriSecu is a small yet powerful Private Security Device and GPS tracker that leverages Smartphone app or Google map to accurately pinpoint the exact location of a person or valuables. The device, measuring 60mm x 47mm x 17mm, uses advanced GPS tracking technology to instantly detect the accurate location, and GPRS/GSM network to instantly communicate the same to you via Smartphone app. The PriSecu device, attached to your loved ones or valuables, can be located via iOS or Android apps or through our website, www.prisecu.com.



No more worries!! Stay tuned with your beloved ones and track their location easily and quickly with PriSecu device!! This way you can keep a watch, though remote, on your loved ones or other assets, taking immediate actions in case of criminal intrusion, emergency health issues, accidents, etc. The device will instantly communicate with you via Smartphone app in case of emergency, enabling you to take quick action. Our device ensures enhanced protection and tracking of:

  • Children
  • Spouse
  • Elders
  • Pet
  • Disable who need help
  • Vehicle
  • Employee
  • Important asset and many more





The PriSecu comes loaded with superb features and functionalities that provides accurate and reliable tracking and security information in a prompt and convenient manner.















  • PriSecu
  • Battery 
  • USB cable
  • Charger
  • Belt Clip
  • User Manual
  • CD and Screw driver
  • 1 Year International Warranty
  • Free life time prisecu.com tracking access and Smartphone Apps free  




PriSecu Apps is releasing iOS and Android apps which will able to control and configure remotely the PriSecu devices. Beside Tracking the unit and listen to the unit, it have more setting as listed below.


Apps Setting : -

  • Set Internet monitor
  • Set IP and port
  • Set Password
  • Set Authorization
  • Set Live Monitor
  • Traffic mode - Set to alert when PirSecu start moving so the unit will send GPS data to monitor platform or mobile phone automatically
  • Sensor alarm - Sensitivity setting so the unit will send alarm message to phone when shake.
  • Speed alarm - When the unit moves exceeding pre set the unit will send SMS alarm.
  • Movement alarm - Set distant from original point to alert for movement.
  • Geo fence - Set Geo fence for the unit to restrict it movement within an area.
  • Check Total mileage calculation
  • SOS - Set Find Me alert target phone number
  • Set Time format
  • Set UDP/TCP
  • Check Status - It will reply SMS. Include: IMEI、speed、battery、position state、time、IP、APN、Port etc.
  • Check Version - It will reply version information
  • Reset - This will back to default settings.
  • and more....





For sponsor that pledge on Dealer Start up kit or Dealership Pack, they will automatically sign up as our dealer. Their information will be listed in our website. All purchase inquiry from area that nearby to them will forward to this dealer. 

Lock Price mean that the price they pledge now will be same when after the campaign price raise back to normal dealer price.

Sole Distributor for a country will be appointed to the sponsor who are the first pledge on Country Sole/Joint Distributor Perk and have business address in the selected country. Only few country will have 2 or 3 Joint Distributor, Country like USA and China.

All dealer purchase from the country with appointed distributor will automatically directed to the country distributor.

All the Sole or Joint distributor for each country will be listed in our website and here.




1.  Did PriSecu work only with GSM network?

  • Yes, PriSecu can be use is most of the country with GSM network, except Japan & South Korean (this countries support only 3G network).

2.  Is that a monthly fee?

  • No, PriSecu come with own free lifetime server and apps. Therefore do not require an additional fee to host the tracking historical data compare to others GPS tracker.
  • However telco fee may apply for your own sim card.

3.  Can one smarts phone track multiple PriSecu?

  • Yes, Our Apps can add multiple units and show multiple units in one map.

4.  What is the different in between others GPS tracker compare to PriSecu?

  • PriSecu come with a waterproof casing compare with others need to special add on a waterproof bag.
  • Our battery life is double up to last for 2 weeks with single charge compare with others only last for a week.
  • Our component chipset/battery is grade A compare to others are using cheap grade B chipset/battery. (Have you used those cheap phone battery before?)
  • We provide One year international warranty as our product has very low warranty rate.

5. Does the device include a true GPS chipset?

  • Yes, PriSecu using GPS Module SIRF3 chip with GPS Sensitivity -159dBm and has GPS Accuracy about 5m.

This campaign have been reposted and now active in HERE  

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/prisecu-personal-gps-tracker--2

story:
Short Summary

 

I was diagnosed with Severe Crohn's Disease in April of 2012 after suffering with what was thought to be food poisoning. After those tests came back negative, for the third time, I really began to worry. I went from a healthy 150 pound guy who exercised regularly to a mere 103 pound guy who could barely make it from the bed to the couch. I lost all fat and muscle and found daily tasks extremely difficult. I found myself letting the days pass by. I failed my spring quarter classes and lost my financial aid due to this disease.

 

For my 5 stays in the hospital and my treatments I accumulated over $68,000 in medical debt. Most of this debt was taken care of through charity but I still owe over $5,000 and even with a job it is very difficult to make any progress toward getting this debt eliminated when I have rent and other bills to pay. I had to stop my treatments because I could no longer afford to pay for them. I was terminated from state medical assitance, after 5 months because I made over the $299 per month maximum they have set. My main goal is to get started back on the treatments I was on so that I may remain a healthy person.

 

Crohn's put a stop on my life, school and work. Even with a job, it barely allows me to cover bills such as rent and eletricity, let alone past medical bills and current medications. I was without health insurance and my hospital bills are enough to make anyone want to climb under a rock. Last year let me know that everyone should prepare for the worst and unexpected.

What I Need

  • I need help paying for my treatments. It costs around upwards of $3000 a treatment every 6-8 weeks. With the amount donated I will be able to start up on my treatments again and hopefully remain on them this time.

 

  • Any donation amount is greatly appreciated.

 

  • I need help getting back on my feet, restarting these treatments will keep my body healty allowing me to remain in school and work more, where I will be able to put more money into the costs of my Crohn's medications.
 

The Impact

  • Many people do not know the pains people with Crohn's Disease face as many sufferes appear to be normal healthy people.

 

  • Any money raised can help me continue my treatments and prevent my body from harming itself so that I may remain in school and work. Every day is a fear that I may have a flare up and end up hospitalized again.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • I ask you to check out some of these websites to get a better idea as to what Crohn's is and what it does to the human body:
  •  CCFA          http://www.ccfa.org/what-are-crohns-and-colitis/what-is-crohns-disease/
  •  Mayoclinic    http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/crohns-disease/DS00104
  •  WebMd        http://www.webmd.com/ibd-crohns-disease/crohns-disease/default.htm
 

Please share this any way you can.

I would like to get the word out there as this seems to be a very unknown disease. It seems the people who know what this is and what it does, only know so because they have someone in their lives that are affected by Crohn's.

story:
Short Summary


I became a nurse so I could help people in real and tangible ways. While in nursing school, I was chosen to study global issues in healthcare at Oxford University in England. This opened my eyes to the hardships many people face and made me want to provide healthcare where it's in short supply--in the developing world.

Now I have my chance! During October, I will be volunteering in Ghana with an organization called Global Crossroad. I've been given the opportunity (and privilege) to make a difference firsthand with the skills I've developed as a critical care nurse. This will be the learning experience of a lifetime, and I know that my training will be put to great use.

Before I leave for Ghana, I'd like to gather donations that I can present to the Magro Maternity and Health Center, where I will be volunteering during the month of October.

What We Need & What You Get


My travel and living expenses are already paid for, but I hope to gather contributions for basic medical supplies. The Magro Maternity and Health Center is located in Kasoa, approximately 45 miles from the capital city of Accra. The center needs latex hand gloves, testing kits, medical equipment, and much more.

According to Partners in Health, about 800 women die in pregnancy and childbirth worldwide each day, primarily in developing countries, and the main cause of death is lack of skilled healthcare.

No matter how much money I raise, ALL of it will be going directly to the clinic. Any amount helps, as basic medical supplies are in short supply. 

I will be providing updates as often as I can on my experiences in Ghana, and the patients I see in the health center.


    The Impact

    Magro Maternity and Health Center provides healthcare to more than 20,000 local residents. The clinic sees up to 70 patients per day, mostly pregnant women and children, and employs approximately 15 permanent staff. Magro Health Center is a small clinic, with one general counseling room, one recovery room, one delivery room, and five wards with beds. The majority of patients are there for maternity and general health check-ups. Patients are treated for malaria, fever, malnutrition, cough, and dysentery.

    With your contribution, together we can help raise the funds to supply the clinic with basic health supplies and equipment. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you are unable to contribute at this time, or even if you can, please help me get the word out. Let's give this clinic a contribution unlike any it has seen before! Share my video on Facebook or through email; whatever form of sharing you think appropriate.

      Together we can make a difference! I'll donate my time; you can help me get the people of Kasoa, Ghana, the medical supplies they need.

story:
Short Summary

*****************

We are a small group of students from the Metro Detroit region passionate about world health. We come from varied backgrounds, including medicine and technology, and different levels of experience in international medical missions. Inspired by the unmet medical needs of people in certain regions of the world, we have been working for over a year and a half to develop a medical records system capable of acquiring essential medical information in the high-volume, fast-paced environment of a short term clinic. Our focus is on the needs within Haiti, but we hope that our system will be useful to such teams around the world; in other underdeveloped countries as well as underserved regions of developed countries. Our project is associated with Henry Ford Health System in Detroit, Michigan, USA.

There are thousands of NGO's that travel to Haiti each year, many of them medically focused. These teams often stay in Haiti very briefly, at times treating thousands of patients in under a week. Doctor-patient interaction is frequently limited to only 10 minutes to accommodate such high volumes. While these groups are well-intentioned and offer momentary relief, the insufficient  communication between them results in a lack of continuity in health care. Since each group has no access to the previous records of their patient population, and therefore no data to use in preparation of their trip, the medications they bring and the care they provide is mostly based on guess work. Furthermore, the lack of data collection overlooks the opportunity to study the effectiveness of temporary international medical relief teams. Our aim is to collect and store patient information effectively and collect the information in such a way that does not impede the work of such high-volume, fast-paced transient medical clinics.


What We Need & What You Get

*****************

The software, known as fEMR (pronounced like 'femur'), has been piloted once already under that name 'EasyEMR'. We have more work to do, but it is quite functional and ready for used in the field. Our system is running on old, donated laptops and netbooks. This hardware is inadequate.

Our newest version of the system is meant to run on a laptop computer transmitting an 'ad hoc', local wireless network connected to a slew of iPads at stations in the clinic. We require funding to obtain the iPads with accessories such as keyboard attachments as well as hardware to amplify the signal transmitted from the master computer. Additionally, we require funding for a stipend to cover the personal costs of a programmer knowledgeable of the system who will be on standby for tech support whenever the system is in the field as well as to aid in further software development.

We are aiming for a total of $6000 to meet these goals. Here is the breakdown of where the money will go:

$2,346 to cover the cost of 6 iPads

$504 to cover the cost of Insurance for these iPads

$726 to cover the cost of protective covers for the iPads

$240 to cover the cost of attachable keypads for the iPads

$240 to cover the cost of 6 solar powered chargers

$444 to cover the cost of additional accessories such as laptop battery support and hardware to enhance signal tranmission range

$1500 to cover the cost of IT support for 1 year from a recent Computer Science graduate from Wayne State University who is knowledgeable about the system


Rewards for all donors of any level will include recognition on the wallpaper of all system screens; bolded with a minimum $30 donation. Donors of $500 or more will have their names etched into the back of one of the iPads. Donors of more than $1000 will become honorary co-developers and will receive acknowledgement in any future publicity of the system. Donors of $3000 or more will be provided a free position to travel with us to Haiti on a future trip involving this medical records system.

The Impact

****************************

The goal is to be able to help adequately prepare each medical team that volunteers to work in specific communities in Haiti, while also increasing the continuity in patient care. The medical teams will be able to communicate with each other via data which have not previously been maintained. This will help to prevent problems like revaccination and enhance care of chronic medical conditions. We also hope to be able to provide the paients with a PDF copy of their medical record so they can share their medical history with other clinics and Haitian hospitals, a liberty not many have had before.

During one clinic on the island of La Gonave, Haiti, in June of 2010, a medical team from Wayne State University's School of Medicine encountered a patient with gestational diabetes who was experiencing an acute diabetic attack. As the only option, the team paid to transport the patient by boat to Port-au-Prince to get treatment, but the patient did not make it to the hospital in time and passed away. Had the team known about this high-risk pregnancy during their preparation, they would have been sure to pack insulin with their supplies, an injection that would have saved her life. The use of an electronic record keeping system can significantly reduce the likelihood of cases like this and therefore has the potential to save lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

*******************

We are focused on gathering the funds needed to obtain the hardware that the system requires. However, there are other ways to contribute. Software is always in development and we always need new ideas for software development. Networking with international medical teams is also necessary to test and use our system in the field. And, of course, we love to travel and meet new people doing great things in the world. Come with us!
story_txt:
Short Summary*****************We are a small group of students from the Metro Detroit region passionate about world health. We come from varied backgrounds, including medicine and technology, and different levels of experience in international medical missions. Inspired by the unmet medical needs of people in certain regions of the world, we have been working for over a year and a half to develop a medical records system capable of acquiring essential medical information in the high-volume, fast-paced environment of a short term clinic. Our focus is on the needs within Haiti, but we hope that our system will be useful to such teams around the world; in other underdeveloped countries as well as underserved regions of developed countries. Our project is associated with Henry Ford Health System in Detroit, Michigan, USA.There are thousands of NGO's that
travel to Haiti each year, many of them medically focused. These teams often stay
in Haiti very briefly, at times treating thousands of patients in
under a week. Doctor-patient interaction is frequently limited to only 10
minutes to accommodate such high volumes. While these groups are
well-intentioned and offer momentary relief, the
insufficient  communication between them results in a lack of continuity in health care. Since each group has no
access to the previous records of their patient population, and
therefore no data to use in preparation of their trip, the medications they
bring and the care they provide is mostly based on guess work. Furthermore,
the lack of data collection overlooks the
opportunity to study the effectiveness of temporary international medical
relief teams. Our aim is to collect and store patient information effectively and collect the information in such a way that does not impede the work of such high-volume, fast-paced transient medical clinics.What We Need & What You Get*****************The software, known as fEMR (pronounced like 'femur'), has been piloted once already under that name 'EasyEMR'. We have more work to do, but it is quite functional and ready for used in the field. Our system is running on old, donated laptops and netbooks. This hardware is inadequate.Our newest version of the system is meant to run on a laptop computer transmitting an 'ad hoc', local wireless network connected to a slew of iPads at stations in the clinic. We require funding to obtain the iPads with accessories such as keyboard attachments as well as hardware to amplify the signal transmitted from the master computer. Additionally, we require funding for a stipend to cover the personal costs of a programmer knowledgeable of the system who will be on standby for tech support whenever the system is in the field as well as to aid in further software development.We are aiming for a total of $6000 to meet these goals. Here is the breakdown of where the money will go:$2,346 to cover the cost of 6 iPads$504 to cover the cost of Insurance for these iPads$726 to cover the cost of protective covers for the iPads$240 to cover the cost of attachable keypads for the iPads$240 to cover the cost of 6 solar powered chargers$444 to cover the cost of additional accessories such as laptop battery support and hardware to enhance signal tranmission range$1500 to cover the cost of IT support for 1 year from a recent Computer Science graduate from Wayne State University who is knowledgeable about the systemRewards for all donors of any level will include recognition on the wallpaper of all system screens; bolded with a minimum $30 donation. Donors of $500 or more will have their names etched into the back of one of the iPads. Donors of more than $1000 will become honorary co-developers and will receive acknowledgement in any future publicity of the system. Donors of $3000 or more will be provided a free position to travel with us to Haiti on a future trip involving this medical records system.The Impact****************************The goal is to be able to help adequately prepare each medical team that volunteers to work in specific communities in Haiti, while also increasing the continuity in patient care. The medical teams will be able to communicate with each other via data which have not previously been maintained. This will help to prevent problems like revaccination and enhance care of chronic medical conditions. We also hope to be able to provide the paients with a PDF copy of their medical record so they can share their medical history with other clinics and Haitian hospitals, a liberty not many have had before. During one clinic on the island of La Gonave, Haiti, in June of 2010, a medical team from Wayne State University's School of Medicine encountered a patient with gestational diabetes who was experiencing an acute diabetic attack. As the only option, the team paid to transport the patient by boat to Port-au-Prince to get treatment, but the patient did not make it to the hospital in time and passed away. Had the team known about this high-risk pregnancy during their preparation, they would have been sure to pack insulin with their supplies, an injection that would have saved her life. The use of an electronic record keeping system can significantly reduce the likelihood of cases like this and therefore has the potential to save lives.Other Ways You Can Help*******************We are focused on gathering the funds needed to obtain the hardware that the system requires. However, there are other ways to contribute. Software is always in development and we always need new ideas for software development. Networking with international medical teams is also necessary to test and use our system in the field. And, of course, we love to travel and meet new people doing great things in the world. Come with us!

story:
Short Summary

Ana Mango is an awesome person and she needs to succeed!

Supporting Ana Mango in her massage therapy career will give you the satisfaction of making a difference in not only her life, but those lives she touches! Literally.

What She Needs

  • Donations for a massage table
  • Donations to support her operational costs
  • Donations to support her licensing fees

The Impact

Many people will be impacted by Ana's success. Her friends love her and support her and this is where we can show the love!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate even $5 please spread the word about Ana and connect her with awesome places to work once she has her FL massage therapist license!

story: Hi my name is Cassidy Erickson. A little over a year ago I had my daughter Luna. When she was born I had to have an emergency C - Section. Not even two weeks later I got an infection in my incision and went to stay with family up in Spokane. There I was feeling really sick and when I went to the hospital they told me that I had to have my gallbladder removed. As of this point I was on maternity leave at my job and they wanted to promote me to full time bookkeeper, unfortunately I was unable to take the position and return to work at that time. My surgery was set for the following Monday, but that Friday I went into the ER and was admitted into the hospital for Gallstone Pancreatitis. Since then I've been in and out of the hospitals, seeing both a primary care doctor and specialist. I've been seen at the ER so many times that I'm pretty sure I'm a regular now. About 6 months ago they finally found something. I have what is known as C-Diff which is a toxin in my intestines that has been slowing taking over. I have been through 3 different antibiotics and still have this disease. There is only one more possible option for hope before this disease kills me and that is a transplant at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota. So if you are still reading this and interested in helping me any donation would help. I have to pay 5,000 up front just to so they will see me. I've been on medicaid and collecting welfare for this last year do to being sick and not being able to work. Medicaid will not pay outside the state of Washington, so everything must come out of pocket. I'm 24 years old with a one year old. I am not the type of person to ask for help, but I'm also not the type to give up without a fight. My daughter deserves the world and I'm fighting to live so I can give it to her. November 17th is when I head to Minnesota anything anyone would be willing to donate would be great.

story:
We are Co-Workers for Carlos!

We work for a company in PA (called Dyventive) and we are all like family!!  (If you can't feel like family with the people you spend the majority of your day with then why do you work where you do?)  Well, one of our family members is sick and while we can raise some money -- we know Carlos needs more help than we can offer alone. 

Carlos has cancer - but this goes far beyond an admirable battle against that single worthy opponent!   Before Carlos embarked on his battle with cancer he was already amazing to us; married with two children and BOTH of his children are autistic.  Thanks to Autism, Carlos already knows what it means to fight adversity every single day. 

Now he fights for his own life and his own health having been diagnosed with cancer, and facing a foot amputation as soon as possible. 

This campaign is not solely about raising funds for Carlos -- sure he will need some care and lifestyle modifications -  but it's about taking care of his family too.  Autism can take up many of the family’s resources. 

We are giving all we can – but our small group cannot raise enough to really help him without your help.  Please consider giving to Carlos and his family.  If you can help with only $1 we understand, we love you and we thank you!!   We simply ask that you share this on your social network to help spread our dear friends need – because $1 from a few thousand people could change his life right now.   

Our gratitude could never sufficiently be expressed but we thank you so very much.   

We Need Every Dollar We Can Get 

  • Carlos will have amputation surgery of his foot.  In his absence, his children wont just need day care -- they will need specialized care with people experienced with their needs. 
  • Carlos will be out of work but we won't let him be alone.

Your biggest contribution!!

Next to your financial donation, your biggest contribution to this cause is to spread the word.  If you would PLEASE share this in your social network we would be eternally grateful. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you have skill or piece of knowledge we don't know we are missing.  Perhaps you have had a foot amputated and you can tell some ways to make our workplace better for Carlos.  Please include remarks with your donation and use the indigogo share tools.  Thank you!!

story:
My Story

Hey everyone, my name is Chase. I am 26 years old, from Hollister, NC. I am the father of two beautiful children, Chase Jr. and Isabella, who are living separately with their mother. My girlfriend, Darla is amazing, and I consider her 2 children my own. We call live outside of Henderson, NC in the country. We also have 2 dogs: Max and Raven, who also help me out on a regular basis. Our goal is $15,000 for medical expenses and disease related costs. Here is my journey up until today.

 

In 2006 I began having multiple boils and cysts on my scalp. Over time, these abcesses began tracting forward from the top of my neck on up to the front of my hairline. Several specialists, antibiotics, and surgeries later, I was referred to Duke Dermatology for an assessment.

Near the end of 2010, I was diagnosed with Hidradenitis Suppurativa(H.S) and Dissecting Cellulitis of the Scalp, both advanced. By this point, the disease had been pretty much unchallenged in my body, and the effects were irreversable. Hidradenitis now affects almost 25% of my lower body and Dissecting Cellulitis has taken over my scalp. Hidradenitis is incurable, not usually life threatening, but can be debilitating. The areas of my body affected are the worst, the buttocks and the groin areas. No conventional or practical treatments have worked, including intralesional steroid injections, high dose quinolones(Levaquin), excision and packing, or long term antibiotic courses. The diseases are so far advanced, that my dermatologist and myself made the decision to go forth with the most radical, yet most successful method of treatment.

On July 31, 2012, I stepped into the Duke Cancer Center for my first round of external beam radiation. I know, you're probably thinking I have some form of cancer. Nope, but at times I wish, cancer is a lot simpler to explain, although it is a much worse diagnosis, and I do not wish to take anything away from a cancer patients fight and struggle. My first day of a two week process went pretty well, nothing too painful or scary. Fast foward to week 2, day 8/11. By this time the radiation had began to build in my body, and even at such a low dose, it has taken its toll on me. My skin is becoming irritated, the lesions in my buttock region have become inflamed and swollen to the point that it hurts to sit, stand walk or lay down. The techs were always so nice, and caring. But to walk out or the room and see a 14 year old kid receiving chemo, I just wanted to apologize for wasting everones time. There was a man that walked into the cancer center the same day as me. This man was about the same height as me(6'4-6'5 or so) but in much better shape, with his wife and daughter, both beautiful and smiling. I saw this same man on the last day of my first round, in a wheel chair, covered with a blanket, and so weak from weeks of chemotherapy that he could barely hold his head up. That scared me for this very reason: one major but rare complication of H.S. is cancer and the fact that I subjected myself to radiation and the disease has progressed as far as it has increases my chances. I am terrified of winding up in that wheelchair, too weak from chemotherapy to walk myself to my car.

Today, September 2, 2012, I have noticed some progress stemming from radiation. Some smaller sites are beginning to shrink or have already disappeared; well, not disappear, but reduced to scar tissue. Now, I am able to stand for a longer period of time, can complete my work shift without taking excessive standing or walking breaks. And, I can now do some activities with my children. Last week, I took Chase Jr, Isabella, and Darla's daughter, Aliya for a ride on the lawn mowers dump cart. While I was in pain, it was minimal with the help of medication, I was able to do something other than lay down. Depression isn't so much of an issue any more. I was in a bad funk, thinking that God hated me, and I was doing something wrong to be punished with suffering. Now, I am kind of seeing a different light. Darla, oh boy, Darla has been amazing. Putting up with the pain, the sleepless nights, lack of help around the house, helping out with wound care and remembering to take medications. I honestly dont know what I would do if she weren't around. I still see the worry in her eyes, but its not as bad, almost like she sees the light at the end of the tunnel like me. In the words of my father "She's my saving grace". Couldn't have been more right dad. Most women would have been done when intimacy became a problem. There were times when she couldn't even hug me tight for fear of putting pressure on a painful abcess or worse causing one to burst under the skin. But she's been here, right here the whole time. And I dont see her going anywhere. I know you are probably tired of reading, so i'll get to the point.


Now, for the reason that I need donations. My medical bills are piling up, and I have to go back in 2.5 weeks to discuss the next step in radiation therapy. If the treated areas show enough improvement, I can begin radiation therapy on my scalp and face. If not, I may have to repeat treatments on my lower body. I have had to take more time from work than anticipated, and have put myself and family behind in everything including my medical costs. Also, my dermatologist is double treating with high strength antibiotics(Cyclosporine), that are quite pricey even with my health insurance. The money would help out with travel costs to drive an hour each way to my therapy, assessments, and unplanned doctors visits. I'm not sure if I am asking for too much or too little, but anything would help out more than nothing. My main reason for opting for such radical treatment is my children. I want to be able to go outside and run and play with them. I also want to be able to seek other employment to help move to a better location, and school district. Currently with having to stay at home due to pain from abcesses, doctors visits and radiation therapy, I cannot take another job and lose my health insurance, and my FMLA approval. I tried in the spring to take another job, and my condition worsened and I was unable to get the medications I was prescribed to help control the flare-ups. Luckily my previous employer was gracious enough to re-hire me with my benefits intact and provided me medical leave for therapy. However my deductible was fairly high and I wound up taking a pretty big portion of my medical bills on 100% and there are still a lot of procedures and visits that are not covered due to the nature of my condition. I appreciate any donations small or large and will keep updating my status as time goes on. Thank you.

story:
Five years ago, my mom and I started a tradition of riding the Little Red Riding Hood bike ride together. Our 80 mile ride was something we both looked forward to. Last year, less than two days before we were supposed to ride, doctors found three very large tumors in my abdomen and diagnosed them as ovarian cancer. Five days after the discovery, I was scheduled for surgery to remove the tumors and stage my cancer. My mom thought we should cancel our ride. She worried that 80 miles would be too much for me to ride with those tumors inside. I wouldn't hear of canceling our ride. It was my last chance to be normal before having surgery and facing chemotherapy. 

This year we want to ride as part of the Huntsman Hometown Heroes. They are a non-profit organization at the hospital where I received my treatment. To be a part of their group we each need to raise at least $750. The money goes directly to the hospital to fund cancer research.

I can't wait to be able to ride again. I finished chemotherapy on Janurary 7th and on the 23rd I am hoping my doctors declare me cancer free! As a 22 year old collegiate athlete, going through ovarian cancer was the last thing I expected to be doing with my life. I love to ride and spending this time with my mom really means a lot. To be able to support cancer research while I'm doing what I love would be the best.

story:
During my travel in Indonesia I met the 21 year old Erwin.
When he told me the story about how he broke his leg 3 years ago, and how he will remain disabled for life if it isn't taken care of quickly,  I felt I had to do something for him, so here we are.
Erwin's leg is still broken and it needs surgery urgently.

While he still can, he works hard to save money for the $15.000 surgery. But in all honesty, with the $150 a month he earns now, he alone won't be able to get the money together to save his leg in time.

That's why I hope we can all work together to get his leg fixed and give him back this basic necessity that he needs so hard in order to survive and to be there for his community.

 

What We Need

$15000 is needed for surgery and hospital costs.
$2500 for revalidation and after care.

With your help we hope to reach the entire goal within time.
If we don't, we will need to setup additional campaigns. We contacted several charity organizations but they only support projects for groups of people and no individual cases.
So it's just you and us for Erwin's leg. Time is critical to save it.

 

The Impact

Erwin won't be disabled for the rest of his life and wil be able to walk again.

Erwin always tries to support his family and community as much as he can.
It will be very hard for him to find a job and keep on going with a broken leg.
story_txt:
During my travel in Indonesia I met the 21 year old Erwin.When he told me the story about how he broke his leg 3 years ago, and how he will remain disabled for life if it isn't taken care of quickly,  I felt I had to do something for him, so here we are. Erwin's leg is still broken and it needs surgery urgently.
While he still can, he works hard to save money for the $15.000 surgery. But in all honesty, with the $150 a month he earns now, he alone won't be able to get the money together to save his leg in time. That's why I hope we can all work together to get his leg fixed and give him back this basic necessity that he needs so hard in order to survive and to be there for his community.
 


What We Need
$15000 is needed for surgery and hospital costs.$2500 for revalidation and after care.
With your help we hope to reach the entire goal within time. If we don't, we will need to setup additional campaigns. We contacted several charity organizations but they only support projects for groups of people and no individual cases. So it's just you and us for Erwin's leg. Time is critical to save it.
 


The Impact
Erwin won't be disabled for the rest of his life and wil be able to walk again.
Erwin always tries to support his family and community as much as he can.It will be very hard for him to find a job and keep on going with a broken leg.

story:
Who are we? What are we doing? 

    We are a group of students from Anne Arundel Community College and we have been assigned to choose a non-profit organization, and help them raise money! We have chosen to do the American Cancer Society in order to help cure cancer, as well as, to help the families in which someone has cancer. Cancer can be very awful for any family. Hints the reason on why we have chosen American Cancer Society.

 Imagine... 

      Imagine if u will... You get home from a long day at work and your spouse comes up to you and says "Honey, I have a breast cancer!!” What would your initial reaction be? Wouldn't you like to know that there are people in the world that care about your spouse and family? I know I would. Any donations help. Five dollars could help make equipment more efficient and help detect cancer more quickly. Twenty dollars could pay a scientist for an additional thirty minutes to find what helps prevent cancer. Believe it or not any dollar helps and is needed and is appreciated.

 Can't afford to donate?

    Its okay, we understand that it is a tough economy and not everyone can help donate. But, you can still help believe it or not. Help get the word out!! 

 

Thank you so much for your help/donations.

story:
The time is right for a dramatic show of support by Africans on behalf of LGBT rights in Africa, but to do so, they need your help.

Help us continue to exceed our goal so we can send another delegate to the African Commission!

1. Justice 4 Eric: The Short Version

This opportunity has emerged from the work of the St. Paul's Foundation for International Reconciliation*, which has been working closely with several LGBT groups in Cameroon, especially the Cameroonian Foundation for AIDS (CAMFAIDS). In July 2013, just weeks after speaking out publicly about the threats and violence targeting these groups, CAMFAIDS' executive director, Eric Ohena Lembembe, was brutally tortured and murdered in his own home. Since his murder, his colleagues at CAMFAIDS and other LGBT organizations have faced escalating threats.

Eric's tragic fate is all too familiar in Cameroon, where people who are LGBT and their advocates regularly face threats, arrests, torture, and mob attacks.

We are outraged by the Cameroonian's Government's first official response to Eric's murder expressed this week in Geneva by the Cameroonian Ambassador:

“So I reject this alleged case of this young man who allegedly was found dead as a result of his homosexuality. Distinguished Ambassadors, ladies and gentlemen, these are just things that have been made up. Look at the details of this person’s life and you will understand why he died.”

We have raised enough funds to sent two representatives to impress upon African leadership these attitudes are not acceptable. Homosexuality is NOT A REASON TO DIE in any country. We are now upping our goal to make sure we have a delegation of at least three Cameroonians to these conferences in October.

But these kinds or responses and threats have not silenced these brave Cameroonian human rights defenders. Instead, they worked on a 45-page report to the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights detailing the Government of Cameroon's dismal record on LGBT rights. Now, they need your help to travel to the African Commission next month to make their case in person.

With your financial assistance, Africans can stand up for the human rights of LGBT Africans -- the most effective and far-reaching kind of advocacy on that continent. Their voices must be heard. Eric's death must become a wake-up call for Africans to stop persecuting their gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, intersex, and queer brothers and sisters. With your help, the African Human Rights Commission can set a precedent for all African countries that LGBT rights are human rights. Not just in Europe and the United States. But all across Africa, too.

* St. Paul's Foundation for International Reconciliation is a California-based non-profit that engages in dialogue and coalition-building between secular and religious organizations that share the same values and outcomes for marginalized people, particularly women and LGBT people.

2. Justice 4 Eric: We Can Make It Happen

The goal is to send a broad spectrum of Cameroonian organizations working on LGBT issues to attend the African Human Rights Commission session in October. Each additional person who can attend will increase the attention that LGBT rights will receive, amplifying their powerful message and showing strength in numbers.

Each $2,750 will sponsor the travel of one additional representative. We have two sponsored already and are hoping for an additional one so need to raise $5500 in this campaign. The costs we need to cover for two people are:

  • Airfare from Cameroon to the Gambia (where the African Commission meets): $1,600 each
  • Registration for the 3-day NGO Forum before the session: $100
  • Visa to enter the Gambia: $100
  • 7 nights in a hotel, plus food and ground transportation: $700
  • The remaining $250 (each) costs are approximate fees for this online campaign paid to the site.

Our goal is $2,500 each person (and $250 for Indiegogo fees for each person totalling $5,500); meeting that goal will mean one more representative from another Cameroonian organization working on LGBT rights will be able to attend the October 2013 African Commission session and the pre-session NGO Forum. But if we exceed our goal and raise $5,000, representatives from two different groups can go. And if we raise $7,500, we can send representatives from three groups. The more we raise, the more Cameroonian LGBT organizations' voices will be heard, and the more impact their voices will have with the African Commission and in the forum with hundreds of other African human rights groups. (Any funds that do not meet one of the $2,500 benchmarks will go toward improving the security and impact of LGBT groups in Cameroon, especially CAMFAIDS, which has suffered the most from homophobic violence.)

Your donation will make a real difference on the ground in Africa. To show our appreciation, we also have some great gifts for you!

  • For your donation of $25, you'll receive a video called "Love Heals Homophobia," featuring four important straight African American clergy talking about their journeys to full acceptance of LGBT people and how to create congregations that celebrate diversity.
  • For your donation of $100, you'll receive a copy of From Wrongs to Gay Rights: Cruelty and Change for LGBT People in an Uncertain World. This book includes chapters by Eric Ohena Lembembe (who was also a journalist), Erasing 76 Crimes blog editor Colin Stewart, Reverend Albert Ogle of St. Paul's Foundation, Miles Tanhira, Andy Kopsa, Rachel Adams, and Clare Byarugaba.
  • For your donation of $1,000, you'll receive a Granite Pillar Award from St. Paul's Foundation. Emblazoned with St. Paul's logo and your name, these table-size awards honor those pillars of our community who literally support others in their work for global justice.

3. Justice 4 Eric: The Impact

Your donation will make a tangible contribution to promoting LGBT rights in Africa. LGBT people face severe persecution in Cameroon:

  • Many countries prohibit private, consensual, adult sexual conduct between people of the same sex. But unlike many of those countries, the Government of Cameroon is increasingly enforcing its law, even applying it to non-sexual conduct like ordering a particular drink in a bar or sending an affectionate text message.
  • A vigilante youth group patrols the streets twice a week--and they say the government endorses their work--to "hunt down" homosexuals and either beat them up or hand them over to police for arrest. The group has marched the streets calling for people to kill LGBT Cameroonians.
  • Since Eric's murder, threats against other LGBT activists have escalated.
  • A leader of Cameroon's own Commission for Human Rights recently warned LGBT activists -- just weeks before the African Commission meeting and another meeting of the U.N.'s Human Rights Council -- that if they "denigrate their country abroad in international bodies and then complain that they are insecure when they return to their home country -- they themselves are responsible for what happens. They know they will be put down."

For further information, please read the report that these groups on the ground in Cameroon will present to the African Commission. You'll see just how dire conditions really are.

These brave LGBT groups in Cameroon are uniquely positioned to honor Eric's legacy and deliver the message that LGBT rights are human rights. When groups from the United States or Europe raise these concerns, the Government of Cameroon dismisses them, saying it's a matter of "African culture." In fact, when the Government of Cameroon submitted its latest report to the African Commission in April, it didn't mention LGBT rights at all. It asserts that homosexuality is a "western import" and falls back on references to "African values" -- values that apparently condone the torture and murder of people because they are trying to provide services to people who are at risk of HIV/AIDS. Of course, these values are not at all true African values -- but the best people to make this argument are Africans themselves.

When Africans stand up and speak for the rights of LGBT Africans, the Government of Cameroon has a harder time coming up with a plausible response. These groups want to attend the pre-session NGO Forum to meet with hundreds of other African human rights organizations to build momentum for the LGBT rights movement in Africa. If, this October, the African Commission calls out the Government of Cameroon on its horrible human rights record for LGBT people, it could set a precedent for all of the other African countries that persecute people who are LGBT. Half of the countries in the world where it's illegal to be LGBT are in Sub-Saharan Africa, and Africa is more intolerant of homosexuals than any other continent, so a bold statement from the African Human Rights Commission could be groundbreaking.

There are signs that the African Human Rights Commission will be receptive. In July, the Commission's expert on human rights defenders sharply condemned Eric's murder and called for the Government of Cameroon to conduct a prompt and thorough investigation. The Government of Cameroon, meanwhile, has stalled its investigation and lashed out at LGBT rights groups for making the government "look bad" in the western media.

These advocates speak eloquently about human rights conditions in Cameroon and the need for change. They'll use this opportunity to build support among other African human rights organizations and to press their case with the African Commission. We've worked with them in the past, including most recently to raise funds for Eric's funeral. So you know your donation will be put to great use.

4. Justice 4 Eric: Other Ways To Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are real ways you can help. First, learn about what's going on in Cameroon. Second, spread the word about this campaign -- use the handy indiegogo share tools! Third, encourage the bloggers you read to devote more attention to LGBT rights in Africa. Finally, stay tuned for updates from the African Human Rights Commission meeting October 18-25 -- if our colleagues can be there, the meeting has the potential to be a turning point for LGBT rights in Africa!

FRENCH VERSION

Aidez nous à envoyer des militants LGBTI camerounais à la Commission africaine des droits de l'homme et des peuples!

Quelques semaines seulement après avoir parlé publiquement des menaces et la violence ciblant les groupes LGBTI au Cameroun, le Directeur de CAMFAIDS, Eric Ohena Lembembe  a été brutalement torturé et assassiné dans son propre appartement. Depuis son assassinat, les menaces n’ont cessé mais elles n'ont
pas fait taire les défenseurs camerounais des droits humains.


Au lieu de cela, trois d’entre-eux ont travaillé à un rapport de 45 pages qui doit
être présenté à la Commission africaine des droits de l'homme et des peuples,
l’équivalent régional du Conseil des Droits de l’Homme des Nations Unies. Il
détaille le triste record des violations des droits des personnes LGBT par le
gouvernement du Cameroun.


Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour que les représentants d'un large éventail
d'organisations camerounaises se rendent le mois prochain à la Commission
africaine des droits de l'homme et des peuples et au forum des ONGs la
précédant. Les militants LGBTI camerounais doivent pouvoir participer à ses
travaux et faire valoir leur point de vue. Nous aimerions être presents en
nombre et souhaiterions envoyer au moins 3 militants pour amplifier notre
message et montrer notre force et notre union.

Le montant nécessaire à la participation d’un militant s’élève à 2750 USD chaque personne.
Soit:

- Billet d'avion du Cameroun à la Gambie (où siege la Commission africaine)

1600$

- Inscription au Forum des ONG de 3 jours, avant la session : 100 $

- Visa pour entrer en Gambie : 100 $

- 7 nuits dans un hôtel, nourriture et transport sur place : 700 $

-Indigogo 250$

Aidez-nous à nous faire entendre! Aidez nous à envoyer des militants LGBTI camerounais à la Commission africaine des droits de l'homme et des peuples!

Une partie des fonds sera consacrée à l'amélioration de la sécurité et de
l'impact des groupes LGBT dont CAMFAIDS au Cameroun. Cette operation est
realisée en collaboration avec la Fondation St Paul Fondation pour la
réconciliation internationale dont l’appel à dons  avait déjà permis de couvrir
les frais liés à l’enterrement d’ Eric Ohena Lembembe.. Basée en Californie et
bénéficiant du statut 501 (c ) pour les associations à but non lucrative, la
Fondation s'engage dans le dialogue et la formation de coalitions entre les
organisations laïques et religieuses qui partagent les mêmes valeurs pour les
personnes marginalisées , en particulier les femmes et les personnes LGBT.

story:
HÖMDRY is the first compact, affordable, hygienic, cordless and environmentally friendly Home Hand Dryer. 

As we continue to introduce HÖMDRY and break down all the beneficial and revolutionary features, we will first explain the problems HÖMDRY addresses:

  • 99.9% of the population uses either, some sort of reusable towel, paper towel or nothing at all to dry their hands after washing them in their home whether it be in their kitchen, bathroom or elsewhere.
  • The problem with drying your hands with a reusable towel is that unless you wash the towel after every use, it will build up with germs and bacteria, making cleaning your hands counter-productive.

  • Bacteria needs three elements to thrive: organic material, warmth and moisture and a used towel provides all three.
  • Towels pick up dead skin cells, get wet and sit in warm and moist conditions in the bathroom.
  • This makes them the perfect home for bacteria.
  • Using paper towels to dry your hands is not an environmentally conscious, hygienic, and financially responsible option.

  • According to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, 28.5% of municipal solid waste produced is paper waste.
  • By using HÖMDRY you will significantly lower your carbon footprint and solid waste production.

 

  • In fact, up to 88% of unused paper towels in the U.S. contain bacteria, which can transfer to your hands. 

 

  • The cost of using HÖMDRY is up to 97% cheaper yearly than using paper towels. 

 

  •  Currently there are alternatives for your home:

  • Unfortunately, they are expensive, clumsy, wired, very difficult to install, in other words there is nothing available that is Built Home Conscious™ like HÖMDRY.

  • Built Home Conscious™ means a product is specifically designed and engineered for home and personal use.
  • There are many products that are dual use: commercial and personal use.
  • However, to be Built Home Conscious™ a product needs to meet certain criteria to be perfectly suited for home use.

 

1. Space Conscious

  • HÖMDRY is specifically sized to fit comfortably in a home bathroom or home kitchen.  

 

  • Standing on it's base, HÖMDRY is 17.91 inches tall, 6.5 inches wide and 9.51 inches deep.  

 

  • Mounted on the wall, HÖMDRY is 22.64 inches tall, 6.13 inches wide and 9.14 inches deep.

 

 2. Easy Installation

  • HÖMDRY comes with everything you need to easily set up on the standing dock and has an easy mounting kit for wall use.
  • A manual for setup is included, but not needed.
  • What's in the box?  Everything below.

 

3. Learning Curve

  • HÖMDRY has little to no learning curve for first time use.

  • HÖMDRY's ON button is triggered by its hand sensor placed exactly where your hands need to be.

 

 4. Life Cycle

  • HÖMDRY is equipped with a lithium-ion battery.
  • On a full charge the wireless battery lasts 1,920 session, and an average of 480 days or 1.3 years.

 

5. Maintenance  

  • The only hands-on maintenance needed is taking out the HEPA filter once every 3 months and cleaning it for under 20 seconds.

 

 6. Accessibility

  • HÖMDRY's wireless functionality is specifically engineered to be used standing on your counter or mounted on your wall.

 

360° View of HÖMDRY and it's components:

 

 

 

  

 

 

 

  • Place HÖMDRY with base on your kitchen or bathroom counter.

OR

  • Use the included mounting kit to secure your mount on wall and place HÖMDRY with its external battery onto the wall mount.

NEXT

  • After washing your hands, place hands underneath the hood of HÖMDRY.
  • Built in sensor will detect your hands and automatically run a patented session of Warm Air and UV Blue Light.
  • Heated HEPA filtered air will blow out at 2x the speed of a normal industrial hand dryer.

FINISHED

  • After 16 seconds.
  • Dry and clean hands.

Facts:

  • Each session last 16 seconds.
  • Our patented process blows heated air the entire 16 seconds and shines our Blue UV Light for the last 8 seconds of each session.
  • Blue UV Light is safe on skin and proven to kill bacteria soap can miss.
  • Charging time takes 3 hours for a full battery.
  • HÖMDRY is safe and the most environmentally cautious option to drying your hands in your home.
  • HÖMDRY is currently the only hand dryer Built Home Conscious™.

Color Options:

  • Available in CHROME (Left)
  • Available in GLOSSY CLEAN WHITE (Right)
  • Limited Quantity Available in MATTE BLACK (Center)

Additional Information:

HEPA FILTER:

  • Included in each box is a built in, removable, reusable custom HEPA filter. 

  • Easily remove your filter to clean once every 3 months.

BASE:

  • Included in each box is charging port that doubles as a stand.

  • Easily charge your HÖMDRY when battery is low.

EXTERNAL BATTERY:

  • Each box includes an external battery that serves as a second battery while HÖMDRY is in the wall mount position.
  • Easily Slide the bottom of HÖMDRY into the external battery when using on the wall mount.

  • The external battery is designed so HÖMDRY can be charged while on the wall and never needed to be removed.

 

 

Stretch Goals:

Check back here as the project progresses to find out more about our planned secret perks.

We have some in mind that we think you're going to love!

 

  

  

About Us:

We're a team with a straightforward vision.  We love building products that solve real world problems.  Our team focuses on innovative, futuristic items.  HÖMDRY was one of those ideas that just clicked instantly.  We couldn't figure out why we had never seen a hand dryer in anyone's home. After researching, we learned that there is nothing built for a home - from all aspects including: size, cost and practicality.  Also, from our research we learned about all the environmental benefits of using a hand dryer instead of paper towels.  As well, we learned about the sanitary benefits of hand dryers over reusable towels.  This was a no brainer and we were excited.  We channeled our excitement and built an amazing product!

What We Bring To The Table:

We've had an amazing journey coming to where we are today with HÖMDRY, and now feel confident we will deliver a true life changing product in a timely matter.  We have extensive skills in the following areas:

  • Manufactoring
  • Design
  • Leadership
  • Retail
  • Project Management

Our Leadership:

Eddie Btesh, CEO, has owned and sold an online business selling electronics in 1999.  Since, he has been leading and advising in various tech ventures.

Jason Rosenbaum, CTO, sold an app development tech company and has since been heavily involved in product development and design.

Kim Lewandowski, COO, has been responsible for bringing over 150 products to market in the last 20 years.

Early Concepts:

 

SOCIAL MEDIA AND PRESS:

 

 

 

Please Click Below & Tag Your Friends That Would Love HÖMDRY!

 

Click Below To Send Out A Tweet To Spread The Word In The Twitter World!

 

Your Support Is What Keeps Us Going!

 

For further press requests, please contact: Press@Homdry.com

 

Questions?

Ask away! Shoot us a message or post a comment and we'll do our best to get back to you with an answer.

 

Risks and Challenges:

The main challenge we face is getting production cost low enough to hit our target price. Based on our set goal, we will be able to produce at an affordable rate. Our team has a combined 100+ years working with manufacturers and hitting key delivery dates with major retailers.

We are working with a trusted manufacturer that our team has developed and produced products with for over 12 years.

We are excited to continue to share the HÖMDRY journey with you
story_txt:
HÖMDRY is the first compact, affordable, hygienic, cordless and environmentally friendly Home Hand Dryer. As we continue to introduce HÖMDRY and break down all the beneficial and revolutionary features, we will first explain the problems HÖMDRY addresses:
99.9% of the population uses either, some sort of reusable towel, paper towel or nothing at all to dry their hands after washing them in their home whether it be in their kitchen, bathroom or elsewhere.
The problem with drying your hands with a reusable towel is that unless you wash the towel after every use, it will build up with germs and bacteria, making cleaning your hands counter-productive.

Bacteria needs three elements to thrive: organic material, warmth and moisture and a used towel provides all three.

Towels pick up dead skin cells, get wet and sit in warm and moist conditions in the bathroom.
This makes them the perfect home for bacteria.
Using paper towels to dry your hands is not an environmentally conscious, hygienic, and financially responsible option.

According to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, 28.5% of municipal solid waste produced is paper waste.
By using HÖMDRY you will significantly lower your carbon footprint and solid waste production.
 In fact, up to 88% of unused paper towels in the U.S. contain bacteria, which can transfer to your hands.  The cost of using HÖMDRY is up to 97% cheaper yearly than using paper towels.   Currently there are alternatives for your home:Unfortunately, they are expensive, clumsy, wired, very difficult to install, in other words there is nothing available that is Built Home Conscious™ like HÖMDRY.

Built Home Conscious™ means a product is specifically designed and engineered for home and personal use.
There are many products that are dual use: commercial and personal use.
However, to be Built Home Conscious™ a product needs to meet certain criteria to be perfectly suited for home use.
 1. Space Conscious
HÖMDRY is specifically sized to fit comfortably in a home bathroom or home kitchen.   Standing on it's base, HÖMDRY is 17.91 inches tall, 6.5 inches wide and 9.51 inches deep.   Mounted on the wall, HÖMDRY is 22.64 inches tall, 6.13 inches wide and 9.14 inches deep.  2. Easy Installation

HÖMDRY comes with everything you need to easily set up on the standing dock and has an easy mounting kit for wall use.
A manual for setup is included, but not needed.
What's in the box?  Everything below.
 3. Learning Curve
HÖMDRY has little to no learning curve for first time use.
HÖMDRY's ON button is triggered by its hand sensor placed exactly where your hands need to be.  4. Life Cycle

HÖMDRY is equipped with a lithium-ion battery.
On a full charge the wireless battery lasts 1,920 session, and an average of 480 days or 1.3 years.
 5. Maintenance  The only hands-on maintenance needed is taking out the HEPA filter once every 3 months and cleaning it for under 20 seconds.  6. Accessibility
HÖMDRY's wireless functionality is specifically engineered to be used standing on your counter or mounted on your wall. 360° View of HÖMDRY and it's components:
 


 

 
     Place HÖMDRY with base on your kitchen or bathroom counter.ORUse the included mounting kit to secure your mount on wall and place HÖMDRY with its external battery onto the wall mount.NEXT
After washing your hands, place hands underneath the hood of HÖMDRY.
Built in sensor will detect your hands and automatically run a patented session of Warm Air and UV Blue Light.
Heated HEPA filtered air will blow out at 2x the speed of a normal industrial hand dryer.
FINISHED
After 16 seconds.
Dry and clean hands.
Facts:
Each session last 16 seconds.
Our patented process blows heated air the entire 16 seconds and shines our Blue UV Light for the last 8 seconds of each session.
Blue UV Light is safe on skin and proven to kill bacteria soap can miss.
Charging time takes 3 hours for a full battery.

HÖMDRY is safe and the most environmentally cautious option to drying your hands in your home.

HÖMDRY is currently the only hand dryer Built Home Conscious™.
Color Options:
Available in CHROME (Left)
Available in GLOSSY CLEAN WHITE (Right)

Limited Quantity Available in MATTE BLACK (Center)

Each box includes an external battery that serves as a second battery while HÖMDRY is in the wall mount position.
Easily Slide the bottom of HÖMDRY into the external battery when using on the wall mount.
The external battery is designed so HÖMDRY can be charged while on the wall and never needed to be removed.
